metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: PHP - What are Abstract Classes and Methods?
Abstract classes and methods are when the parent class has a named method, but need its child class(es) to fill out the tasks.
content.html: Abstract classes and methods are when the parent class has a named method, but need its child class(es) to fill out the tasks.

content.text: An abstract class is a class that contains at least one abstract method. An abstract method is a method that is declared, but not implemented in the code.
content.html: An abstract class is a class that contains at least one abstract method. An abstract method is a method that is declared, but not implemented in the code.

content.text: An abstract class or method is defined with the abstract keyword:
content.html: An abstract class or method is defined with the abstract keyword:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpabstract class 
    ParentClass {  abstract public function someMethod1();  
    abstract public function someMethod2($name, $color);  abstract 
    public function someMethod3() : string;}?>

content.code:
<?phpabstract class 
ParentClass {  abstract public function someMethod1();
abstract public function someMethod2($name, $color);  abstract
public function someMethod3() : string;}?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpabstract class 
    ParentClass {  abstract public function someMethod1();  
 abstract public function someMethod2($name, $color);  abstract 
 public function someMethod3() : string;}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
abstract class ParentClass {
  abstract public function someMethod1();
  abstract public function someMethod2($name, $color);
  abstract public function someMethod3() : string;
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpabstract class 
    ParentClass {  abstract public function someMethod1();  
    abstract public function someMethod2($name, $color);  abstract 
    public function someMethod3() : string;}?>

content.text: When inheriting from an abstract class, the child class method must be defined with the same name, and the same or a less restricted access modifier. So, if the abstract method is defined as protected, the child class method must be defined as either protected or public, but not private. Also, the type and number of required arguments must be the same. However, the child classes may have optional arguments in addition.
content.html: When inheriting from an abstract class, the child class method must be defined with the same name, and the same or a less restricted access modifier. So, if the abstract method is defined as protected, the child class method must be defined as either protected or public, but not private. Also, the type and number of required arguments must be the same. However, the child classes may have optional arguments in addition.

content.text: So, when a child class is inherited from an abstract class, we have the following rules:
content.html: So, when a child class is inherited from an abstract class, we have the following rules:

content.code_html:
<?php
// Parent class
abstract class Car {
  public $name;
  public function __construct($name) {
    $this->name = $name;
  }
  abstract public function intro() : string;
}

// Child classes
class Audi extends Car {
  public function intro() : string {
    return "Choose German quality! I'm an $this->name!";
  }
}

class Volvo extends Car {
  public function intro() : string {
    return "Proud to be Swedish! I'm a $this->name!";
  }
}

class Citroen extends Car {
  public function intro() : string {
    return "French extravagance! I'm a $this->name!";
  }
}

// Create objects from the child classes
$audi = new audi("Audi");
echo $audi->intro();
echo "<br>";

$volvo = new volvo("Volvo");
echo $volvo->intro();
echo "<br>";

$citroen = new citroen("Citroen");
echo $citroen->intro();
?>

I'm a $this->name!";   }}// Create objects from the child classes$audi = new audi("Audi"); echo $audi->intro();echo "

// Create objects from the child classes

content.text: The Audi, Volvo, and Citroen classes are inherited from the Car class. This means that the Audi, Volvo, and Citroen classes can use the public $name property as well as the public __construct() method from the Car class because of inheritance.
content.html: The Audi, Volvo, and Citroen classes are inherited from the Car class. This means that the Audi, Volvo, and Citroen classes can use the public $name property as well as the public __construct() method from the Car class because of inheritance.

content.text: But, intro() is an abstract method that should be defined in all the child classes and they should return a string.
content.html: But, intro() is an abstract method that should be defined in all the child classes and they should return a string.

content.text: Let's look at another example where the abstract method has an argument:
content.html: Let's look at another example where the abstract method has an argument:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
prefixName("John Doe");echo "
"; echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");?>

content.code:
prefixName("John Doe");echo "
"; echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
prefixName("John Doe");echo "
"; echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");?>

content.code_html:
<?php
abstract class ParentClass {
  // Abstract method with an argument
  abstract protected function prefixName($name);
}

class ChildClass extends ParentClass {
  public function prefixName($name) {
    if ($name == "John Doe") {
      $prefix = "Mr.";
    } elseif ($name == "Jane Doe") {
      $prefix = "Mrs.";
    } else {
      $prefix = "";
    }
    return "{$prefix} {$name}";
  }
}

$class = new ChildClass;
echo $class->prefixName("John Doe");
echo "<br>";
echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
prefixName("John Doe");echo "
"; echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");?>

content.text: Let's look at another example where the abstract method has an argument, and the child class has two optional arguments that are not defined in the parent's abstract method:
content.html: Let's look at another example where the abstract method has an argument, and the child class has two optional arguments that are not defined in the parent's abstract method:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
prefixName("John Doe");echo "
"; echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");?>

// The child class may define optional arguments that are not in the parent's 
    abstract method

content.code:
prefixName("John Doe");echo "
"; echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
prefixName("John Doe");echo "
"; echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");?>

// The child class may define optional arguments that are not in the parent's 
    abstract method

content.code_html:
<?php
abstract class ParentClass {
  // Abstract method with an argument
  abstract protected function prefixName($name);
}

class ChildClass extends ParentClass {
  // The child class may define optional arguments that are not in the parent's abstract method
  public function prefixName($name, $separator = ".", $greet = "Dear") {
    if ($name == "John Doe") {
      $prefix = "Mr";
    } elseif ($name == "Jane Doe") {
      $prefix = "Mrs";
    } else {
      $prefix = "";
    }
    return "{$greet} {$prefix}{$separator} {$name}";
  }
}

$class = new ChildClass;
echo $class->prefixName("John Doe");
echo "<br>";
echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
prefixName("John Doe");echo "
"; echo $class->prefixName("Jane Doe");?>

// The child class may define optional arguments that are not in the parent's 
    abstract method
